title: USS Sitka (APA-113)
text:
USS "Sitka" (APA-113) was a in service with the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> from 1945 to 1946. She was sold into commercial service in 1947 and was scrapped in 1976.
History.
"sitka" was named for <a href="Sitka%2C%20Alaska">Sitka, Alaska</a> (a town on the western coast of <a href="Baranof%20Island">Baranof Island</a>). The name was originally assigned to PF-94 on 30 August 1943, but she was renamed on 7 February 1944. "Sitka" (APA-113) was laid down on 2 February 1944 under Maritime Commission contract (MC hull 875, Type C3-S-A2) by the <a href="Ingalls%20Shipbuilding">Ingalls Shipbuilding</a> Corporation of <a href="Pascagoula%2C%20Mississippi">Pascagoula, Mississippi</a>; launched on 23 June 1944; sponsored by Mrs. Mary Lee Council; and commissioned on 14 March 1945 with Captain Charles F. M. S. Quinby in command.
1945–1946.
"Sitka" departed <a href="Mobile%2C%20Alabama">Mobile, Alabama</a> on 20 March 1945; and, after stopping at <a href="New%20Orleans">New Orleans</a> for supplies, arrived at <a href="Bolivar%20Roads">Bolivar Roads</a>, <a href="Galveston">Galveston</a> on 28 March 1945 for shakedown. However, her shakedown lasted only four days, as she received orders to report to <a href="Newport%2C%20Rhode%20Island">Newport, Rhode Island</a> for duty as training ship for pre-commissioning crews being-formed there. "Sitka" arrived at Newport on 6 April and, for two and one-half months, she trained crews of new amphibious and auxiliary vessels in seamanship and gunnery. Relieved by the , "Sitka" sailed from Newport for <a href="Norfolk%2C%20Virginia">Norfolk, Virginia</a>, on 25 June.
After a brief overhaul, "Sitka" sailed from Norfolk on 6 July with a replacement draft of several hundred <a href="United%20States%20Marine%20Corps">marines</a>, as well as other troops and cargo. Transiting the <a href="Panama%20Canal">Panama Canal</a> on 11 July, "Sitka" called at <a href="Pearl%20Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a> from 24 July to 3 August and at <a href="Eniwetok">Eniwetok</a> on the 11th and 12th, before arriving at <a href="Guam">Guam</a> on the 15th. She discharged her troops and cargo at Guam, and sailed for <a href="Manila">Manila</a> on 27 August to embark troops for the occupation of Japan. Departing Manila on 7 September, the transport arrived at <a href="Yokohama">Yokohama</a>, Japan on the 13th and began disembarking troops and equipment two days later.
"Sitka" departed Yokohama on the 19th; and, between 23 and 27 September, embarked units of the <a href="6th%20Marine%20Division%20%28United%20States%29">6th Marine Division</a> at Guam for the occupation of <a href="Tsingtao">Tsingtao</a>, China. She arrived at Tsingtao on 11 October and disembarked her troops and cargo on the 15th and 16th. After returning to Manila on the 23rd for a week of upkeep, she embarked units of the 52nd Chinese National Army at <a href="Hai%20Phong">Hai Phong</a>, <a href="Indochina">Indochina</a> on 3 November; and disembarked them at <a href="Qinhuangdao">Chinwangtao</a> in northern China on the 13th. After a week at <a href="Taku%20Forts">Taku</a>, she departed China on the 21st and arrived at Manila on the 26th to join "<a href="Operation%20Magic%20Carpet%20%28World%20War%20II%29">Operation Magic Carpet</a>," the transportation of war veterans home to the United States. "Sitka" sailed from Manila on 28 November carrying homeward-bound servicemen and arrived at <a href="Seattle%2C%20Washington">Seattle, Washington</a> on 14 December.
"Sitka" remained at Seattle for repairs until sailing to Saipan and Guam on 30 January 1946. The ship arrived at <a href="San%20Pedro%2C%20Los%20Angeles">San Pedro</a> on 23 February and got underway for the east coast on 1 March. On 16 March she arrived at Norfolk for deactivation.
In mercantile service, 1946–1976.
"Sitka" was decommissioned on 14 May 1946, returned to the <a href="War%20Shipping%20Administration">War Shipping Administration</a> the next day, and struck from the <a href="Naval%20Vessel%20Register">Naval Vessel Register</a> on 5 June 1946. She was sold into mercantile service to <a href="Pope%20%26amp%3B%20Talbot">Pope & Talbot Lines</a> in 1947 and renamed SS "P&T Trader; resold in 1957 to <a href="Moore-McCormack%20Lines%2C%20Inc.">Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc.</a>, and renamed SS "Mormacguide; and resold in 1964 to the American Foreign Steamship Company and renamed SS "American Condor" in 1964. The ship was scrapped in 1976.
